title: What is the difference between ethnology and social anthropology? - Quora

response.answer_text: What is the difference between ethnology and social anthropology? As other answers have stated, they are mostly synonymous. To the extent the words are both used at the same time by the same person, they may show a slight difference in emphasis. “Ethnology” is simetimes used to describe the process of conducting anthropological fieldwork — that is, gathering data — and then writing up studies of the particular ethnic group or other culture or subculture that the fieldworker studied to learn about their culture. The end product of such work, the written study, is called an “ethnography.” “Social anthropology” is the broader term and “ethnology” could be considered a completely included subset of social anthropology. The broader term also includes the comparative analysis of different cultures, and the development and testing of various hypotheses and theories of social organization and culture.

Arguably, none. This is a regional terminology difference for the branches of anthropology. They are: ArchaeologyLinguisticsEthnology (or “Cultural Anthropology”; “Social Anthropology.” The term “Social Anthropology” is used mostly in the UK curriculum.)Physical Anthropology (or “Biological Anthropology,” again a term more commonly used in the UK.)Applied AnthropologyThe terms “ethnology,” “social-” and “cultural anthropology” are widely and interchangeably used in referring to the study of ways of life. Anthropologists may then specialize in sub-branches within a respective branch, such as ethnography, wherein an extensive ethnographic study for a focus area is completed. Within “physical-” or “biological anthropology,” there are sub-branches such as forensic anthropology, and so on. So you see, both “ethnology” and “social anthropology” are equally-weighted terms for anthropological branches.
